newsitem.title: GERMANY: Victoria-Allianz role in merger could be problem.
newsitem.headline: Victoria-Allianz role in merger could be problem.

text.p: German insurer Victoria Holding AG said on Friday that Allianz AG's potential involvement in the merger designed to create the ERGO insurance group could raise cartel-related problems.

Victoria announced late on Thursday plans to merge with the Hamburg-Mannheimer group, which is 80 percent owned by Muenchener Rueckversicherungs AG and 20 percent owned by Allianz. The merger has yet to be approved by the cartel office.
The resulting company, with some 21 billion marks ($12 billion) in premiums income, would become Germany's second largest insurance company after Allianz.

Victoria chief executive Edgar Jannott, speaking at the company's shareholder meeting, acknowledged that the German Cartel Office might refuse to sanction the merger unless Allianz, Germany's leading insurer, pulled out.
Should that be the case "we would not be against it," he said.
Allianz would have roughly 10 percent of the ERGO group should the merger go ahead.
Allianz said it did not plan at present to alter its share holdings but acknowledged that the merger might bring about a change.
